newsitem.title: GERMANY: Europe-wide transport plan needed - German minister.
newsitem.headline: Europe-wide transport plan needed - German minister.

text.p: German Transportation Minister Matthias Wissmann said on Friday European nations should jointly map out plans for trans-continental transport corridors that make greater use of railways.
In a radio interview, Wissmann said he would raise the idea at a conference of European transportation ministers in Berlin next week.
Countries have until now planned transportation mostly at the national level, but the need for continental planning has increased, he said.

Truck traffic has boomed dramatically in the last several years because eastern Europe's old state-run railways are weak. Germany, as a transit country, was overloaded by trucks travelling between east and west, he said.
As an example of possible efficiencies, he pointed to the "East Wind" freight rail shuttle linking Berlin, Warsaw, Mink and Moscow.

Wissmann on Thursday unveiled a plan to spend 36 billion marks on German rail expansion over the next five years. Under the proposal, which included building 20 terminals for switching freight from railways to trucks, Bonn would spend 7.2 billion marks per year and Deutsche Bahn AG 6.4 billion marks.
Last year the European Parliament voted to spend 300 million European currency units in 1997 on 14 trans-European transport projects, but most improve links within western cities.
